Indications and contraindications

Indications for the use of glucagon include:

  • Hypoglycemia
  • Beta-blocker overdose
  • Calcium channel blocker overdose
  • Epinephrine-resistant anaphylaxis
  • “Steakhouse syndrome” (a condition where a bolus of food gets stuck in the lower esophageal segment); glucagon may relax the lower esophageal sphincter, allowing the food to pass into the stomach.

Glucagon is absolutely contraindicated in pheochromoytoma, since the excessive adrenaline produced by these tumors in combination with glucagon may lead to a severe hyperglycemic state.

For beta blocker overdose, 3-5 mg of glucagon is injected via rapid IV push, followed by an IV drip of 0.07 mg/kg/hour.
